importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article reflects the current state of food supply conditions in Gaza following the US-brokered ceasefire, highlighting the urgency of humanitarian intervention at this specific moment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe indicates that the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Gaza is unfolding in real-time, with food delivery levels still below targets despite ceasefire agreements and increased access points.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza remain far below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara — are currently open, severely limiting aid delivery.
The WFP has 26 food distribution points active, up from five, but still far short of the 145 it aims to operate across Gaza.
The US-brokered ceasefire is critical to sustaining humanitarian access and preventing famine, especially in northern Gaza.
Hamas has pledged to hand over 28 captives’ remains, having already delivered 13; the Rafah crossing remains closed until this condition is met.
Nutrition supplies are reaching northern Gaza via southern routes, but not in sufficient quantities to meet needs.
Many Palestinians are storing food due to fears that the ceasefire may end and supplies could be cut off again.
Current food deliveries are sufficient for only half a million people for two weeks.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating humanitarian food aid globally.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to assessing and reporting on the current state of food delivery to Gaza, providing authoritative data and calling for increased access to crossings.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory under Israeli military control, heavily affected by conflict and humanitarian crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Gaza Strip is the primary recipient of humanitarian food aid, and the article discusses how food access is critically limited due to restricted crossings and conflict.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Israel and Gaza, located in the southern part of the Gaza Strip.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is one of the only two currently operational crossings into Gaza, making it vital for food aid delivery to the region.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim in Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Israel and Gaza, located in central Gaza, known in Israel as Kissufim.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing is one of the two currently operational points for humanitarian aid, contributing to the limited flow of food supplies to Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed due to political conditions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The closure of Rafah prevents a major potential route for humanitarian access into northern Gaza, exacerbating food insecurity in that region.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza, currently blocked to WFP operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted permission to use this key route, preventing it from distributing food to northern Gaza areas, where needs are highest.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s 20-point peace plan is cited as a framework for restoring humanitarian access and full aid delivery to Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who has publicly stated that the Rafah crossing remains closed until Hamas hands over captives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu’s position directly affects the opening of additional crossings, thereby influencing food supply capacity in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Palestinian political and militant organization that controls Gaza and has agreed to return captives’ remains as part of ceasefire terms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas’s conditional cooperation on returning captives is a prerequisite for the reopening of the Rafah crossing and broader humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A military wing of Hamas responsible for security and operations in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Qassam Brigades announced the exhumation and return of two Israeli captives’ bodies, signaling a step toward fulfilling the ceasefire agreement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food deliveries to Gaza have increased slightly after the US-brokered ceasefire but remain critically short of the 2,000-tonne daily target, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily through just two crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara. Despite expanding to 26 distribution points, the WFP still falls far short of its goal of 145. The Rafah crossing with Egypt remains closed, and the WFP has no access to the Salah al-Din Street, blocking aid to northern Gaza. Humanitarian aid is reaching only limited areas, and many Palestinians are storing food due to fears of renewed conflict. The article emphasizes that sustained ceasefire and full opening of crossings — including Rafah — are vital to preventing famine and saving lives in Gaza.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
